Fig. 1 NO conversion as a function of reaction temperature with 5%H2O over (A) the CeO2 and WaCeOx (a=0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) catalysts under GHSV of 40,000 h−1. (B) W0.18CeOx catalyst under GHSV of 40,000 and 100,000 h−1. (C) Activity stability test with reaction time at 170 °C. (D) Influence of SO2 and H2O on activity at 200 °C. (Reaction conditions: [NO]=[NH3]=1000 ppm, [O2]=3%, H2O = 5% and N2 as the balance gas, GHSV = 40,000 h−1). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns (A) and Raman spectra (B) of the WaCeOx (a = 0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) catalysts. R. China ⁎ Corresponding author. Bimetallic WaCeOx (a = 0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) catalysts were synthesized for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR). The influences of W on structure, activity and surface properties were investigated by XRF, XRD, Raman, TEM, N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-TPR, O2/NH3/SO2-TPD, XPS, and in-situ DRIFTS. The characterization results show that the W/Ce ratio has a great effect on the NH3-SCR activity. The different catalytic activities of WaCeOx are mainly attributed to the acidity change, especially the increase of B-acid content plays a major role in enhancing low temperature activity. W0.18CeOx exhibits excellent low-temperature NH3-SCR activity, SO2/H2O resistance and N2 selectivity with a broad activity window (190–490 °C) with 5%H2O. Moreover, good activity window (235–460 °C) can be maintained even the catalyst treated with 5% H2O at 800 °C for 12 h, showing especial hydrothermal stability. Thus, it can be summarized that W0.18CeOx is regarded as outstanding catalyst for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Ce oxide based catalyst W addition Acidity influence Selective catalytic reduction Low-temperature activity 1 Introduction The removal of nitrogen oxide (NOx) from the atmosphere is one of the greatest challenges in environmental pollution, with the development of industrialization and the burning of fossil resources. It can destroy the ozone layer, form acid rain, lead to photochemical smog [1–3]. To deal with the serious damages of NOx, the government departments of all countries in the world have established extremely strict regulations and policies to control NOx emissions [4]. The NH3-SCR process is the most efficient de-NOx technology at present [5]. The exhaust emission temperature from cement, chemical plants and steel mills etc. is less than 300 °C, but the effective operation window of the commercial V-W(Mo)-Ti catalysts in the pain between 300 and 400 °C [6]. Therefore, the exploitation of a catalyst suitable for low temperature SCR reaction has important practical significance for the remove of NOx from the stationary sources of non-large power plants and the protection of atmospheric environment. For NH3-SCR catalysts, the redox capacity and acidity play an important role in enhancing the catalytic efficiency. It is generally believed that the stronger the redox capacity is, the better the low temperature NO conversion is, but at the same time, the worse the N2 selectivity is at relatively high temperature [7]. In addition, the higher the relative content of B acid on the catalyst surface, the better the low temperature NO conversion activity [8,9]. Ce is often used as active ingredient or support in the NH3-SCR catalysts [10–13] due to its valence electron layer structure of 4f15d16s2, 4f and 5d orbital electrons are easy to transfer in unsaturated state, and the electron transfer between Ce4+/Ce3+ is easy to form oxygen vacancies and improve oxygen mobility [14], showing excellent oxygen storage/release capability. However, pure CeO2 catalyst has moderate redox capacity and weak acidity, generally, cerium-based catalysts commonly show NO conversion activity at medium and high temperatures. Some researchers have tried to improve the NO conversion of Ce-based catalysts by increasing the acidity, but to a lesser extent [15,16]. Among the transition elements, Nb, W and Mo are commonly used to augment the acidity of Ce-based catalysts. The WCeOx catalysts prepared by shan et al. proved that W can significantly improve the NO conversion of the Ce-based catalysts, even under the test conditions of high space velocity and water, but the performance of the sample calcined at high temperature decreased significantly [17]. Shan et al. also demonstrated that the strong interaction between W and Ce can increase the dispersion and charge imbalance of the active species, indicating that WCeOx catalyst has excellent NO conversion [18]. However, its low temperature activity is unsatisfied due to its poor redox capacity. Chen et al. prepared the WCe catalysts with different proportion of W/Ce by co-precipitation, in which the Ce3W2 catalyst revealed 100% NO conversion in the operation temperature window of 250–450 °C. However, H2O and SO2 showed a great negative effect on the reaction of the catalyst [19]. To improve the de-NOx effect, some researchers synthesized the catalysts by loading a certain amount of WO3 on CeO2 with different morphologies (nanocube, nanorod, and nanopolyhedra). Due to its special structure, the larger specific surface area of the catalyst can increase the adsorption and activation of the reactants, and the addition of WO3 can increase the acid content of the catalyst. 5%WO3/CeO2 with mesopore structure especially exhibited wide activity temperature window (200–420 °C) of >95% NO conversion, and an excellent N2 selectivity [20]. Xiong et al. synthesized a novel tungsten-doped CeO2 catalyst by the spread self-combustion method using A sweet potato starch as bio-template [21]. A strategy of mechanochemical self-assembly was used to synthesize CeWOx catalysts in solvent free condition for the abatement of NOx (> 90% 210–440 °C). However, the low temperature activity is poor at high space velocity [22]. Zhan et al. prepared a series of highly ordered mesoporous WO3(x)-CeO2 nanomaterials catalysts using KIT-6 as hard template, in which WO3(1)-CeO2 presented the best catalytic performance with 100% NO conversion at 225–375 °C and good alkali metal resistance. However, the sulfur tolerance is poor, that is, the NO conversion is only 81% when the SO2 is 100 ppm at 300 °C, and the N2 selectivity is less than 80% above 300 °C [23]. Although these catalysts with special morphology and structure promote the activity of SCR, the complex preparation process is not conducive to practical application. Furthermore, it is well known that the redox capacity of Ce oxides can be reduced after doped/loaded a large number of W species in the Ce based catalysts, which was not conducive to the low-temperature NO conversion of the catalysts. In our previous works, we found that a small amount of W can make the Cu0.02Fe0.2WaTiOx catalysts maintain a moderate oxidation and significantly increase the number of acid sites on the catalyst (especially B acid sites). The addition of W in Cu0.02Fe0.2WaTiOx catalysts plays a considerable role in tuning the synergy effect between the redox ability and acidity on NO conversion and resistance to H2O and SO2 [7]. Therefore, considering that a large amount of W addition usually reduces the oxidizing reducibility of the Ce based catalyst and leads to the poor low temperature activity, we attempted to promote low temperature competence and broaden the temperature window by increasing the acidity of the catalyst, especially the acid level of B. In this paper, a series of WaCeOx catalysts with different mole ratio of W/Ce was synthesized via co-precipitation method. The effects of W/Ce ratio on SCR properties and physical-chemical properties were systematically studied by various tests. We paid attention to the influence of surface acidity on the activity. It was suggested that the addition of a small amount of W could significantly increase the surface acid content of the catalyst and thus enhance the activity and N2 selectivity of WaCeOx samples. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The cerium nitrate hexahydrate and ammonium metatungstate (Brought from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.), were taken as Ce and W sources, respectively. NH3·H2O (25–28%) (Brought from Tianli Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) was used as precipitant. WaCeOx (a = 0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) catalysts were synthesized using cerium nitrate hexahydrate and ammonium metatungstate as the precursor by co-precipitation method. Firstly, solution A obtained by mixing 0.02 mol cerium nitrate and ammonium metatungstate (molar ratio of W/Ce = 0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) was added into 80 mL distilled water with a stirring for 30 min. Secondly, a certain amounts of CTAB (molar ratio of CTAB/(W+Ce) = 0.25) was dissolved in 150 mL distilled water thoroughly, stirring in the water bath for 30 min at 50 °C, the obtained solution was denoted as solution B. Thirdly, solution A was added into solution B slowly, and stirred for 60 min. And then 50 mL ammonium hydroxide was added in the mixed solution, then age at 90 °C for 3 h. The precipitate was filtered and washed adequately, then dried overnight at 100 °C and calcined 4 h at 500 °C with heating rate of 1 °C/min in air. For reference, CeO2 was also prepared by the above method. The sample was termed as WaCeOx (a = 0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24), where a represents the theoretical W/Ce molar ratio. 2.2 Characterization A Bruker D8 advanced X-ray diffractometer was used to analyze powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) from 5 ° to 80 ° by Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) scanning at 40 kV and 40 mA. The Micromeritics TristarII 3020 instrument was used to test the specific BET surface area at the liquid N2 temperature (−196 °C). The catalyst needs to be purged with N2 at 150 °C for 5 h before measurement. Raman spectra with 532 nm laser wavelength were collected by Horiba HR Evolution. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometers (Bruker S4 Explorer) was used to test the element contents. Hitachi S-4800 at 20 kV and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEOL JEM-2100). Temperature programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) experiments were implemented with the AutoChem TP-5080 chemisorptions analyzer. The 0.020 g catalyst was heated at 300 °C under O2 flow rate of 30 mL/min for 30 min, and decreasing temperature to 30 °C in the pure O2 atmosphere. Then, the temperature was raised from 30 °C to 950 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in a mixed atmosphere of 5% H2/N2 (30 mL/min). The hydrogen consumption in H2-TPR was calculated by the reduction peak area of each sample by using pure CuO as the standard sample. Temperature programmed desorption of O2 (O2-TPD) curves of the catalyst were measured by TP-5080. Firstly, the 0.100 g catalyst was preheated in 5% O2/N2 mixture for 30 min, and then the He was purged at room temperature. After the baseline signal reached a steady state, the sample was gradually heated up to 900 °C at 10 °C /min at a gas flow rate of 30 mL/min. Temperature programmed desorption of NH3/SO2 (NH3/SO2-TPD) test was performed by the AutoChem TP-5080. For each test, the catalyst mass was weighed at 0.100 g and the catalyst was preprocessed at 300 °C for 30 min in He. Subsequently, the sample is adsorbed with NH3 /SO2 until saturation. Finally, the sample was heated to 500 °C at a velocity of 10 °C /min at a He flow rate of 30 mL/min to record NH3/SO2-TPD curves. The desorption of ammonia per unit peak area is measured by a six-way valve quantitative ring with an accurate volume in the automatic adsorption instrument. Thus, the desorption amount of NH3 in NH3-TPD was calculated by the peak area of each sample. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was measured with Kratos-AXIS ULTRA DLD instruments. And the binding energy was referenced to the C1s orbital of 284.6 eV. The in-situ infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of the catalyst was recored by a Nicolet FT-IR spectrometer (6700) equipped with an in-situ diffuse reflection unit (Harrick), and the MCT detector was cooled with liquid nitrogen. The catalyst was pre-treated at 350 °C in N2 atmosphere for 30 min, then gradually cooled to 150 °C. The background spectrum in N2 atmosphere was collected. The in-situ DRIFTS were detected by accumulating 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1. 2.3 NH3-SCR activity measurements The catalytic performance of catalyst was determined in the quartz fixed-bed reactor under a steady state, the feed included 1000 ppm NH3, 1000 ppm NO, 3% O2, 100 ppm, 150 ppm or 200 ppm SO2 (if used), 10% H2O (if used), and N2 as a balance gas. The total gas flow rate was 200 mL/min, and the corresponding to gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was approximately 40,000 h−1. The catalysts (0.3 mL) of 40–60 mesh were added in a quartz fixed-bed tube reactor with inner diameter of 5 mm under atmospheric pressure. In order to measure the reaction temperature, a K-type thermocouple was inserted in the center of the catalyst bed. The concentration of outlet gas was continually monitored by Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer with 32 scans. In the first place, the standard curves of NO, N2O, NO2 and NH3 were measured by different concentration of the standard gas. Then, the different gas concentration of different gases on the outlet gas can be computed based on the standard curves and the peak area. NO conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated based on the expressions shown below (1) and (2): (1) NO Conversion = 100 % × [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in (2) N 2 Selectivity = 100 % × ( 1 − [ NO 2 ] out + 2 × [ N 2 O ] out [ NO ] in + [ N H 3 ] in − [ NO ] out − [ N H 3 ] out ) In the above expressions, [NO]out, [NH3]out, [NO2]out and [N2O]out expressed as the concentration of NO, NH3, NO2 and N2O at the outlet, and [NO]in and [NH3]in on behalf of the NO and NH3 air inlet concentrations, respectively. Turnover frequency (TOF) values were calculated according to the following equation: (3) TOF = ( Pv / RT ) X NO m cat β Ce / M Ce In the calculation above, P is the atmospheric pressure at standard conditions (1.01 KPa), v represents the flow rate of NO (0.2 mL/mL =3.33 ×10−9 m3/s), R represents the proportional constant (8.134 Pa m3 mol−1 k−1), T is 298 K, X NO represents the NO conversion at 100, 130 and 160 °C (%), respectively, m cat is the mass of the catalyst CeO2 (0.4100 g), W0.06CeOx (0.4050 g), W0.12CeOx (0.4005 g), W0.18CeOx (0.4000 g), W0.24CeOx (0.4000 g), β Ce refers to the surface Ce content (%) obtained by XPS results and M Ce represents the atomic mass of Ce (140.1 g/mol). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR activity As displayed in Fig. S1, the NO conversion and N2 selectivity were measured without H2O addition over the CeO2, WO3 and WaCeOx (a = 0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) catalysts in the temperature region of 100–490 °C. The pure CeO2 and WO3 catalysts show very poor activity for NOx removal, while WaCeOx catalysts has better NH3-SCR activity. Moreover, the NO conversion is improved with the W/Ce ratio increasing from 0.06 to 0.18, and the W0.18CeOx catalyst shows the optimal catalytic activity, especially at low temperature, where the NO conversion is 100% within 150–490 °C. The ratio of W/Ce increases to 0.24 again, the activity temperature window becomes narrow (160–460 °C), maybe due to the cluster of excess W species on the CeO2 surface. NH3 conversion was measured during SCR without H2O over all catalysts shown in Fig. S1B. It can be seen that NH3 conversion over all catalysts is similar to NO conversion below 330 °C. However, the NH3 conversion at higher temperature is obviously higher than NO conversion over the CeO2 and W0.06CeOx catalysts above 330 °C, and over W0.12CeOx, W0.18CeOx, W0.24CeOx at above 460 °C. In addition, the N2 selectivity is found throughout the test temperature window is significantly improved with the increase of W/Ce ratio (Fig. S1C). The W0.18CeOx catalyst shows near 100% N2 selectivity in the range of 100–490 °C. Combined with N2 selectivity (Fig. S1C), the over-oxidation of NH3 is inhibited with increasing W content for WaCeOx compared with CeO2, leading to high NO conversion and N2 selectivity. The activity of WaCeOx catalysts under simulated real flue gas conditions including 5%H2O is shown in Fig. 1A. The low temperature SCR activity of the CeO2 and WaCeOx catalysts with is slightly lower than that without H2O. CeO2 showed the worst SCR activity, below 65% NO conversion in the test range (100–490 °C). Among the WaCeOx catalysts, the W0.06CeOx catalyst has the worst activity with 100% NO conversion at 250–430 °C. When the W content increases, the W0.12CeOx sample shows better SCR catalytic activity and NO is completely converted in the temperature window of 220–460 °C. Similarly, W0.18CeOx exhibits the best NO conversion by fully converting NO to N2 in the operating temperature range of 190–490 °C. The further increase in the ratio of W (W0.24CeOx) leads to the decrease in the SCR activity. The results suggest that the WO3-modified WaCeOx catalysts has excellent SCR water resistance, and the activity of NH3-SCR over the WaCeOx catalysts shows a volcanic trend with the increase of W content. In particular, the W0.18CeOx catalyst provides good low temperature NH3-SCR denitrification activity and N2 selectivity, with far wider activity window. In addition, to evaluate its performance in practical applications, the W0.18CeOx catalyst was tested for NH3-SCR with H2O under high GHSV, as shown in Fig. 1B. Notably, the NO conversion remains 100% between 220 °C and 490 °C even under GHSV of 100,000 h−1. 3.2 Effect of high temperature treatment on activity In-situ regeneration after catalyst deactivation has the advantages of low cost and convenience operation, so it is more suitable for long-term practical applications. To decompose the toxic substances such as sulfate deposited on the surface of the catalyst, the catalyst is usually regenerated by high temperature heat treatment, which requires higher thermal stability of the catalyst [8]. According to this demand, the W0.18CeOx sample with the most outstanding performance was selected to test its thermal stability, that is, its SCR activity was measured after calcination at different temperatures of 500, 600, 700 and 800 °C. As revealed in Fig. S3A the NO conversion at low temperature decreases with the increase of the calcination temperature in the range of 500–800 °C, but the N2 selectivity (Fig. S3B) has little change. It is worth noting that the W0.18CeOx catalyst can maintain 100% NO conversion between 220 and 480 °C even when calcined at 800 °C, indicating that W0.18CeOx catalyst has high thermal stability and can be regenerated in-situ for practical application. In addition, it can be seen from Fig. S3C that when W0.18CeOx is calcined at 800 °C for a long time (12 h), the catalytic performance of W0.18CeOx-800 °C-12 h only decreases slightly compared with W0.18CeOx calcined at 800 °C for 4 h, and the NO conversion is 100% in the temperature range from 235 °C to 460 °C. When W0.18CeOx was hydrothermal treated at 800 °C for 12 h with 5% water (named W0.18CeOx-800 °C-12h+H2O), the activity does also not change significantly at low temperature. But the high temperature activity decreases, that is, the NO conversion is close to 100% in the range of 220–430 °C for W0.18CeOx-800 °C-12h+H2O. And as presented in Fig. S3D, the various treatments above have little effect on N2 selectivity. Table S1 shows the SCR properties, reaction conditions, and anti-poisoning performance of some published Ce-based catalysts. For instance, for the WO3(1)-CeO2 nanomaterials prepared by Zhan et al. [23], NO can be completely converted only when the temperature reaches 225 °C, and the NO conversion tends to decrease when the temperature is higher than 350 °C. The NO conversion over the Ce-W catalyst synthesized by Liu et al. decreased from 100% to 84% at 280 °C when H2O (5%) and SO2 (100 ppm) were injected into the flue gas [24]. Although the NO conversion is improved over the reported various Ce based oxides by adding different elements [19,25–30], it is still insufficient compared with the W0.18CeOx catalyst prepared by us. In brief, the W0.18CeOx catalyst exhibits the excellent low temperature activity and wide activity window for NH3-SCR of NO even under the existence of H2O and SO2, especially higher hydrothermal stability. 3.3 Influence of H2O, SO2 on activity Excellent SO2 and H2O resistance of catalyst is an indispensable part of NH3-SCR reaction. Fig. 1C shows the activity stability of W0.18CeOx catalyst with 5% water vapor in the feed at 170 °C. As can be seen from the figure, SCR activity exhibits a small decline (about 2% NO conversion) within 3 h after the addition of water vapor, and the NO conversion gradually stabilizes at around 88% as time goes on. Even after desulphurization, SO2 and water steam usually exist in flue gas under actual exhaust conditions which may lead to catalyst deactivation due to the competitive adsorption of surface residual sulfate and water vapor [31,32]. Therefore, the NO conversion of W0.18CeOx sample was measured at 200 °C when 5% H2O and 100 ppm SO2 were added in the feed together. As shown in Fig. 1D, the NO conversion decreases during the first 4 h. With the extension of time, the NO conversion fluctuates slightly, and it stabilizes at about 65%. As displayed in Fig. S2, a serial of successive experiments was performed to investigate the SO2 and H2O tolerance over the W0.18CeOx catalyst at 230 °C. The NO conversion keeps 100% unchanged when 10% H2O or 100 ppm SO2 is separately added into the feed. And negligible decline of NO conversion (about 1%) can be observed during tolerance test to the high concentration SO2 (200 ppm). In addition, when introduced both 10% H2O and 100 ppm SO2 into the reaction gas together, the NO conversion decreases slightly from 100% to 92.6%, and can restore to 100% after stopping H2O and SO2. When more SO2 (150 ppm) was added to the flue gas, the NO conversion decreases from 100% to 84.6%. However, it can recover to 96.8% when switched off the SO2 and H2O streams. These results confirm that the effects of SO2 and H2O on activity of the W0.18CeOx catalyst are weak and reversible, indicating the significantly high resistance to SO2 and H2O. 3.4 Bulk structure analysis Fig. 2A displays the XRD patterns of the WaCeOx catalysts. It can be found that all the diffraction peaks in the WaCeOx catalysts are assigned to the cerianite CeO2 (PDF#43-1002), and the characteristic diffraction peak of tungsten oxide species is not found, which can be explained by the fine dispersion of W species, the low content of tungsten, or the content of W species below the XRD limit [27]. Moreover, the crystal particle size calculated by the (111) plane of CeO2 decreases gradually with the increase of the proportion of W listed in Table 1, which is smaller than that of CeO2 [18]. It follows that the growth of crystal particles is inhibited due to the input of W, which can make the surface area larger, which is conducive to SCR reaction. The content of W and Ce was measured by the XRF spectrum for W0.06CeOx, W0.12CeOx, W0.18CeOx and W0.24CeOx catalysts, and the W/Ce ratio was calculated as 0.035, 0.08, 0.12 and 0.14, respectively, which is lower than the corresponding theorical values (Table 1). Meanwhile, Raman spectroscopy was demonstrated to study the structure of the catalyst, especially the oxygen vacancy, as shown in Fig. 2B. For all samples, a sharp peak at about 446 cm−1 and another very weak peak at about 590 cm−1 are observed which can be assigned to the F2g vibration mode and the oxygen defect-induced (D) mode of CeO2, respectively [33–35]. Moreover, no extra peaks belonged to WOx are detected for the WaCeOx samples. These results are mutually verified with XRD results. For the WaCeOx samples, the peak at about 466 cm−1 shifts slightly to lower value with the increase in the W content, furthermore the intensity becomes weaker and the half-peak width shows wider and wider, which indicate that the grain size of the WaCeOx catalysts gradually decreases with the expansion of W ratio, consistent with the crystal size value calculated by the XRD results [33]. In addition, the ID/IF2g ratio represents the number of oxygen defects on the catalyst, and its sequence as follows: W0.18CeOx (0.13) > W0.24CeOx (0.11) > W0.12CeOx (0.082) > W0.06CeOx (0.070) > CeO2 (0.021), suggesting more oxygen vacancies on W0.18CeOx. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and BJH pore distribution curve are shown in Fig. S4. All the catalysts show type Ⅳ isothermal curves and type H3 hysteresis loops, which may be due to the aggregation of nanoparticles. The specific surface area (BET) of the WaCeOx catalysts is much larger than that of pure CeO2 (Table 1). The specific surface area the WaCeOx catalysts increases significantly with the doping of W, from 88.3 m2/g to 105.8 m2/g. However, the specific surface area of W0.24CeOx catalyst decreases to 84.0 m2/g, which is interpreted as partial large WO3 particles blocking the pores. Combined with XRD and Raman spectra, the results indicate that there may be a certain interaction between W and Ce species such as formation of Ce-W bond in shorter range on surface of the catalyst [16]. The microstructure and element dispersion of W0.18CeOx catalyst were characterized by TEM, HRTEM and Element mapping tests (Fig. S5). The W0.18CeOx catalyst presents irregular nanoparticles with the size of about 10 nm, which is consistent with crystal size calculated from the XRD data. At the same time, three different interplanar crystal spacing with 0.31, 027 and 019 nm are observed from HRTEM image (Fig. S5B), corresponding to the (111), (200), (220) lattice size of CeO2, respectively. Moreover, no lattice fringes belonging to tungsten oxide are observed. These results indicate that W does not incorporate in the lattice of CeO2, and it is evenly dispersed on the CeO2 confirmed from the mapping image (Fig. S5C–F). Therefore, the combined results of XRD, Raman, TEM and N2 adsorption-desorption suggest that the interaction between W and Ce makes WOx highly dispersion on the CeO2, thus increasing the specific surface area of W0.18CeOx to makes the adsorption capacity of reactants stronger. Fig. S6 shows the XRD patterns of W0.18CeOx catalyst calcined at 500, 600, 700 and 800 °C. When the calcination temperature is increased from 500 °C to 600 °C, the XRD pattern of the W0.18CeOx-600 catalyst is the same as that of the W0.18CeOx-500 catalyst, however, the grain size increases from 10.6 nm to 13.1 nm. This may be the reason for the slight decrease in its catalytic activity. When the calcination temperature is 700 and 800 °C, weak characteristic diffraction peaks of Ce4W9O33 microcrystalline (PDF#25-0192) are detected on W0.18CeOx-700 and W0.18CeOx-800 catalysts. In addition, the crystallinity and particle size increase significantly for the two catalysts. In conclusion, increasing the calcination temperature can promote the growth of the grain size and the formation of Ce4W9O33 microcrystals in W0.18CeOx catalyst, which is not conducive to the SCR activity. 3.5 Oxidation property measurement 3.5.1 Separate NO and NH3 oxidation The redox performance is the central factor to determine the activity of NH3-SCR catalysts. To understand the oxidation capacity of the WaCeOx catalysts, NO and NH3 oxidation experiments were carried out, respectively ( Fig. 3). The effective oxidation of NO to NO2 can significantly accelerate the "fast SCR" process (3NH3+NO+NO2→2N2+3H2O), and improve the de-NOX potency of NH3-SCR at low temperature [36]. The NO conversion during separate NO oxidation reaction is shown in Fig. 3A. The NO conversion of pure CeO2 catalyst increases gradually with the temperature in the range of 100–340 °C, and begins to have a downward trend above 340 °C. For the WaCeOx catalysts, the NO conversion are slightly promoted in the low temperature region (100–280 °C) compared with CeO2, but it is significantly inhibited in the middle temperature region (280–400 °C). Clearly, compared with the studies reported such as Mn oxides [37,38], Cu oxides [39,40] etc. with strong oxidation ability, the promotion of NO oxidation capacity is negligible for the WaCeOx catalysts [41–43]. The results of separate NH3 oxidation are displayed in Fig. 3B. The NH3 starts to be oxidized when the test temperature reaches to 250 °C, and NH3 conversion gets to 100% when the temperature is increased to 430 °C over CeO2. For the WaCeOx catalysts, the temperature of complete oxidation of NH3 moves to a lower temperature, and 100% NH3 conversion at 340 °C over the W0.18CeOx sample, indicating that the addition of W improved the NH3 oxidation capacity of the catalyst. The order of oxidation ability as follows: W0.18CeOx > W0.12CeOx > W0.06CeOx > W0.24CeOx > CeO2. But the catalyst CoMn synthesized by Zhao et al. showed NH3 was completely oxidized at 250 °C [38]. The MoaMnTi10Ox catalysts were prepared by sol-gel by Li et al., where MnTi10Ox completely oxidizes NH3 at 240 °C [35]. Therefore, the NH3 oxidation capacity of the WaCeOx catalysts is higher than that of CeO2, but it is relatively poor compared with previous reported catalysts with strong oxidation ability. 3.5.2 H2-TPR and O2-TPD analysis H2-TPR was conducted to compare the reducibility of the CeO2 and WaCeOx catalysts, and the obtained profiles are illustrated in Fig. 4A. Pure CeO2 catalyst shows three reduction peaks at 382, 525 and 773 °C, in which the first peak at 382 °C can be allied to the reduction of surface adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst [44]; the second peak at 525 °C is well matched with the reduction of surface Ce4+ to Ce3+ induced by lattice oxygen on the catalysts surface [19,28,45]; the third peak at 773 °C is put down to the reduction of Ce4+ in the bulk phase to Ce3+ (bulk lattice oxygen reduction) [19,28,30]. Compared with pure CeO2, the reduction peak of surface oxygen and Ce4+ species on the WaCeOx catalysts gradually shifts to the high temperature direction, suggesting the decrease in the reducibility. However, the reduction peak of the bulk species moves to the low temperature direction, meaning the enhanced mobility of lattice oxygen [46]. Moreover, the initial reduction temperature of the WaCeOx catalysts, especially for W0.18CeOx, is not unchanged obviously compared with CeO2. The hydrogen consumption was calculated by the peak area listed in Table 1, and its order follows as: W0.18CeOx (989 μmol/g) > W0.12CeOx (940 μmol/g) > W0.24CeOx (791 μmol/g) > W0.06CeOx (690 μmol/g) > CeO2 (578 μmol/g). It is worth noting that the hydrogen consumption of the WaCeOx catalysts is higher than that of CeO2, moreover, the hydrogen consumption of the W0.18CeOx catalyst is the highest among these WaCeOx catalysts. Combined with the results of separate oxidation of NO and NH3 and the H2-TPR results, we think the oxidation ability of the WaCeOx catalysts increases slightly compared with CeO2, and showing a volcanic curve with the W content, in which W0.18CeOx exhibits the optimal oxidation ability among them. However, the change of oxidation ability for the WaCeOx catalysts show has little effect on their activity, and it is not the key factor in the enhanced low temperature activity. The surface oxygen species and its mobility on the catalysts was investigated via O2-TPD measurement. As shown in Fig. 4B, for CeO2, the desorption peak at 234 °C is assigned to the surface adsorbed oxygen [47]; the peak at 419 °C is due to desorption of lattice oxygen on the surface of the catalyst [48]; and desorption peaks above 500 °C are caused by desorption of bulk lattice oxygen [49]. For the WaCeOx catalysts, the desorption peak of the bulk lattice oxygen moves to the low temperature direction, and the surface lattice oxygen also shows a similar phenomenon. Meanwhile, the surface adsorbed oxygen content on W0.18CeOx catalyst is obviously higher than that of other catalysts, and promoting the internal circulation of oxygen species on the catalyst, which is conducive to the low temperature SCR reaction. These results are well correlated with those of H2-TPR. 3.6 Surface acidity test Catalysts surface acidity is one of the important factors affecting NH3 adsorption and activation in NH3-SCR process [31,50,51]. Therefore, the surface acidity of the CeO2 and WaCeOx catalysts was gauged by NH3-TPD illustrated in Fig. 5. On catalyst CeO2, two NH3 desorption peaks are observed, in which a strong peak between 30 and 200 °C can be put down to desorption of NH3 on weak acid sites, and a small weak peak between 350 and 450 °C is ascribed to the desorption of NH3 on the strong acid sites. Evidently, the moderate and strong acid sites are formed on the WaCeOx catalysts, moreover, the intensity of the moderate (III) (200–300 °C) and strong (IV) peaks (300–450 °C) increases with the content of W listed in Table S2, suggesting the increase in acid amount of the moderate and strong acid sites. In addition, the amount of the weak acid sites (I+II) on the WaCeOx catalysts also obviously higher than that on CeO2. In short, the acidity of the WaCeOx catalysts is enhanced significantly with the W addition, moreover, the acid amount of the WaCeOx catalysts (a = 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) is over two times higher than that of CeO2. 3.7 Analysis of surface species XPS was used to analyze the surface composition and chemical states of elements on the CeO2 and WaCeOx (a = 0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) catalysts, as shown in Fig. 6. The surface W/Ce ratio is tested to 0.072, 0.15, 0.19 and 0.33 for W0.06CeOx, W0.12CeOx, W0.18CeOx, and W0.24CeOx ( Table 2), while the corresponding measured bulk W/Ce ratio is 0.035, 0.082, 0.12 and 0.14 (Table 1). Evidently, the surface W/Ce ratio is much higher than the bulk W/Ce ratio, which is propitious to improve the surface acidity. As illustrated in Fig. 6A, the Ce 3d XPS was fitted into eight separate units. The sub-bands labeled U1 and V1 represent the initial electronic state of 3d104f1 corresponding to Ce3+; the sub-bands denoted V, V2, and V3 are assigned to the Ce4+ 3d3/2, and the sub-bands named U, U2, and U3 are assigned to the Ce4+ 3d5/2 [52,53]. The binding energy of WaCeOx shifts to high value with the increase in the W content compared with CeO2, suggesting the charger density of Ce is tuned by the W addition. The surface ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) is determined by its peak area. The Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratio over the WaCeOx catalysts is larger than that of the pure CeO2, and its order is as follows: W0.18CeOx (23.0%) > W0.12CeOx (19.4%) > W0.24CeOx (16.3%) > W0.06CeOx (14.7%) > CeO2 (11.0%), in Table 2. Obviously, the content of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) on the surface of W0.18CeOx is higher than that of other samples. In addition, W0.18CeOx exhibits the highest Ce3+ amount (Ce3+ S = 2.40%) that obtained by multiplying the relative content of surface Ce species by the ratio of surface Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+). These results indicate that the addition of W enhances the interaction between W and Ce, making Ce in a lower valence state, which leads to the production of more surface oxygen vacancies. Electron transfer between Ce3+ and Ce4+ causes oxygen vacancies and unsaturated bonds, and a higher ratio of Ce3+ is not only conducive to the generation of oxygen vacancy, but also promotes the redox cycle in SCR reaction. This can help to explain the higher activity of WaCeOx catalysts. Fig. S7 shows the XPS spectrum of W 4f orbit. It can be seen that the peak positions of W 4F 5/2 and W 4F 3/2 move towards the direction of high binding energy with the increase of W content, demonstrating the increase in the electron cloud density of W. Combined with the Ce XPS results, it indicates that the redox cycle (W6++ Ce3+↔W5++ Ce4+) exists in these catalysts derivered from the strong interaction between Ce and W. The O1s spectra of the CeO2 and WaCeOx catalysts were fitted into three distinct peaks (Fig. 6B): the peak attributed to the surface lattice oxygen appears at about 529.9 eV (marked as Oγ); the peak allocated to the surface chemisorbed oxygen found at around 532.3 eV (marked as Oβ); besides the above two peaks, a peak at 532.8 eV is also found named Oα associated with hydroxyl-like groups including chemisorbed water [20,22]. The relative ratios of Oβ to (Oβ +Oγ) (Oβ/(Oβ + Oγ)) on the surface of the catalysts were quantified by the peak area. The Oβ/(Oβ + Oγ) value of W0.18CeOx is much higher than those of pure CeO2 and other WaCeOx samples, which is consistent with the above Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratio. It is noteworthy that the ratios of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) and Oβ/(Oβ + Oγ) are linear relation with the W/Ce ratio over the WaCeOx catalysts (Fig. 6C). As a result, the percentage of Ce3+ increases with the amount of W from 0.035 to 0.12. This indicates that the active species that dominates the whole reaction is Ce3+. Oβ/(Oβ + Oγ) also increases with the increase of the deposition amount of W. Among all WaCeOx samples, the number of Oβ species in W0.18CeOx sample is the largest. The more kinds of Oβ on the surface of the catalysts, the stronger its oxidation capacity. Consequently, the Oβ-rich catalyst more readily oxidizes NO to NO2, facilitating the "fast SCR" reaction. When the amount of deposited W reached W/Ce = 0.14, the ratio of Ce3+ and Oβ was decreased. This may be due to the excessive deposition of W on the surface of CeO2, covering part of the active site, resulting in the decrease of Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) and Oβ/(Oβ + Oγ) ratio, thus the decrease of SCR activity. Fig. 7 shows the relationship between turnover frequency (TOF) values at 100, 130, 160 °C and the surface W content over the WaCeOx catalysts. TOF values were calculated based on the NO conversion with H2O at 100, 130, 160 °C and the surface Ce amount (Table 2) due to it as redox active sites for the WaCeOx catalysts. As displayed in Fig. 7, for each sample, the higher the temperature, the higher the TOF value, and the better the SCR activity. Moreover, it is noteworthy that the TOF value increases from 0.67 h−1 to 4.1 h−1 at 160 °C with the W/Ce ratio from 0.06 to 0.18, and decreases to 2.3 h−1 when the W/Ce ratio is to 0.24, which demonstrates the best low temperature activity over the W0.18CeOx catalyst. It can be observed that the surface W content (Table 2) on different WaCeOx catalysts increases with the bulk W/Ce ratio (Table 1). However, the TOF values exhibits a volcanic curve at each test temperature with increasing the surface W content. In other word, the W0.24CeOx catalyst has more surface W content and acidity, but its TOF value decreases compared with the W0.18CeOx catalyst. It is speculated that large WO3 clusters are formed on the surface of the W0.24CeOx catalyst due to the addition of excess W, which cover on the active site of Ce, resulting in low TOF value. This is consistent with the results of H2-TPR and the XPS results that the surface absorbed oxygen and Ce3+ content decrease. 3.8 In-situ DRIFTS studies 3.8.1 NH3 adsorption To evaluate the change of surface acidity with the addition of W, in-situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption were measured on the CeO2 and WaCeOx catalysts at 150 °C. As shown in Fig. 8A, the bands at 1403, 1437 and 1668 cm−1 can be attributed to asymmetric bending vibrations of NH4 + ions on Brønsted acid (B-acid) site [54,55]. The peaks at 1181 and 1495–1595 cm−1 belongs to the bending vibration of the N-H bond coordinated at the Lewis acid (L-acid) site [32,55]. Two negative bands at 3637 and 3667 cm−1 are assigned to the depletion of the surfaced hydroxyl (-OH) groups [56]. Moreover, it is obvious that with the increase of the W/Ce ratio, more hydroxyl groups are consumed, thus suggesting the formation of more B-acid sites. Notably, there are few B-acid sites and most of L-acid sites on CeO2, but a great many of B-acid sites are generated on the WaCeOx catalysts with W addition. The amount of B-acid and L-acid of each catalyst was calculated (Fig. 8B) according to the acid amount of NH3-TPD (Fig. 5) and the peak area proportion of each acid site obtained by in-situ DRIFTS (Fig. 8A). The Lewis acidity is primary on the CeO2, however, it is observed that Brønsted acid sites increase significantly and the Lewis acid sites decrease along with adding tungsten (Fig. 8B). According to literatures [7,18,20,21,33,54,57,58], it can be concluded that the W addition is easy to form WO-OH groups, thus obtaining more B-acid sites on the surface the WaCeOx catalysts. It is noteworthy that the proportion of B-acid increases linearly with the W/Ce ratio from 0.035 (W0.06CeOx) to 0.082 (W0.18CeOx) and 0.12 (W0.18CeOx), but the increase value of B-acid (7%) from 0.12 (W0.18CeOx) to 0.14 (W0.24CeOx) is obviously lower than that from W0.06CeOx to W0.12CeOx and W0.12CeOx. This may be caused by the formation of large WOx clusters on the surface of the W0.24CeOx catalyst due to excessive amount of W addition. Fig. S8 shows the DRIFTS of the W0.18CeOx and CeO2 catalysts for NH3 adsorption at different temperatures. After NH3 is introduced, bands belonging to NH3 species appear at 1668, 1595, 1543, 1437, 1403 and 1218 cm−1 on the W0.18CeOx catalyst. The peaks located at 1668, 1437 and 1403 cm−1 are assigned to the NH4 + species at the B-acid sites, while the peaks at 1595, 1543 and 1218 cm−1 belong to the coordination NH3 species at the L-acid sites. The intensity of all peaks decreases slowly as the temperature increases, but the peaks at 1668, 1595, 1543, 1437, 1403, 1218 and 1181 cm−1 still remain until the temperature rises to 340 °C. For the CeO2 catalyst, the peaks intensity of the adsorbed ammonia species on B-acid sites (1668 cm−1) and L-acid sites (1595, 1543 1218 and 1181 cm−1), first gets stronger and then becomes weak gradually when the temperature is elevated. The peaks at 1437 and 1403 cm−1 assigned to B-acid sites and 1543 cm−1 (L-acid) disappear at 250 °C, while the corresponding other bands on the B-acid sites and L-acid sites still exist. All peaks disappear as the temperature continues to rise to 310 °C on CeO2. These results demonstrate that there are much stronger acid sites on W0.18CeOx than on CeO2, which is matching with the NH3-TPD results. 3.8.2 NOx adsorption Fig. 9 shows the in-situ DRIFTS of NO+O2 adsorption on CeO2 and W0.18CeOx at 150 °C. Several different peaks can be observed over the CeO2 and W0.18CeOx catalysts at 1601, 1579, 1558, 1535, 1244, 1234, 1217, 1182 and 1031 cm−1 when the NO+O2 mixture is added, corresponding to bridged nitrate (1601 1244, 1234 and 1217,cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1579 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1558, 1545 cm−1), trans-NO2 (1435 cm−1), NO- species (1182 cm−1) and nitrate species (1031 cm−1) [8,59,60]. For the W0.18CeOx catalyst (Fig. 9A), the peak intensity and position did not change significantly after NO+O2 is injected for 2 min. However, the intensity of all peaks increases gradually as the NO+O2 exposure time increases on the CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 9B), and the unstable NO- species (1182 cm−1) and monodentate nitrate (1558 and 1545 cm−1) gradually disappear and transform into the stable bridged nitrate (1244 and 1219 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1579 cm−1), respectively. The results indicate that it is much easier to quickly form stable nitrogen oxide adsorbed species on the surface of W0.18CeOx than that of CeO2, which may be related to more surface oxygen vacancies on W0.18CeOx. 3.8.3 Effect of H2O on adsorption of NH3 and NO Fig. 1A reveals the H2O addition has negative influence on the SCR activity over the W0.18CeOX catalyst below 190 °C, while no influence above 190 °C. To understand the effects on activity caused by H2O, in-situ DRIFTS of adsorption of separate NH3 or/and NOx under adding H2O were tested over the W0.18CeOx catalyst at 150 and 230 °C. As displayed in Fig. 10A, the intensity of the bands appointed to the adsorbed NH3 at 1668, 1595, 1543, 1437 and 1403 cm−1 obviously decreases after adding 1500 ppm H2O in NH3 at 150 °C, demonstrating that H2O presents a clearly restraining effect on the NH3 adsorption. However, H2O exhibits distinctly the promoting effect on the adsorption capacity of NOx on the W0.18CeOX catalyst at 150 °C (Fig. 10B). This may be because the introduction of a small amount of water forms OH species on the surface of the catalyst [61], which is conducive to the formation of NOx into nitrate or nitrite on the surface of the catalyst. These results illuminate the deactivation at low temperature (<190 °C) (Fig. 1A) is attributed to the competitive adsorption of H2O and NH3 on acid sites of the catalyst. It is noteworthy that H2O has almost no effect on the adsorption of separate NH3 and NOx at 230 °C over the W0.18CeOx catalyst (Fig. 10C and D), which also certify the better resistance to H2O at above 190 °C (Fig. 1A and C). 3.8.4 Adsorption of SO2 and its effect on NH3 adsorption In order to further understand the resistance to SO2 on CeO2 and W0.18CeOx samples, the adsorption spectra of SO2 +O2 on the catalysts were measured by in-situ DRIFTS. As shown in Fig. 11A and B, we can observe some bands at 1608 (HSO4 - formed by the binding of SO2 with surface hydroxyl groups), 1427 (symmetric stretching vibrations of gaseous SO2), 1361 (asymmetric stretching vibrations of surface sulfate species and OS double bond), 1299/1219 (symmetric stretching vibrations of OSO), 1111/1133 (bulk sulfate species), and 1026 cm−1 (sulfate with chelating didental groups) [8,59]. Clearly, the adsorption intensity of SO2 on W0.18CeOx is significantly weaker than that on the CeO2 sample, demonstrating that SO2 is not easy to adsorb on W0.18CeOx compared with CeO2. SO2-TPD can also certify it. As displayed in Fig. S9 SO2-TPD curves show three desorption peaks on CeO2, among which the desorption peak below 500 °C is caused by the desorption of SO2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and the desorption peak 757 °C is attributed to the decomposition of the Ce2(SO4)3/Ce(SO4)2 species [62,63]. Compared with CeO2, the W0.18CeOx sample exhibits only a very weaker desorption peak at 718 °C assigned to the decomposition of the Ce2(SO4)3/Ce(SO4)2 species of SO2. This suggests that it is difficult to form surface sulfates species on W0.18CeOx, which can explain the good sulfur resistance for the W0.18CeOx catalyst. Fig. 11C and D shows the effect of SO2 on the adsorption of NH3 on the CeO2 and W0.18CeOx catalysts. It is obvious that there is no significant change in the adsorption band of NH3 on acid sites of the W0.18CeOx catalyst except for the weak band at 1264 cm−1 (asymmetric stretching vibration of OSO). However, it can be observed some strong bands belonged to sulfates species on the CeO2 catalyst. These results also confirm that there is no formation of sulfates species under adding NH3 and SO2 + O2 together, and SO2 does not influence the adsorption of NH3 on the W0.18CeOx catalyst. 3.8.5 Reaction between NO+O2 and pre-adsorbed NH3 species The in-situ DRIFTS of the reaction between NO+O2 and pre-adsorbed NH3 was conducted to explore the reactivity of adsorbed NH3 species over W0.18CeOx and CeO2 at 150 °C. As shown in Fig. 12A, the DRIFTS present mainly the bands of NH4 + adsorbed on B-acid sites (1403 1437 and 1668 cm−1) and the bands of NH3 adsorbed on L-acid sites (1181 1543 and 1595 cm−1) on W0.18CeOx after the catalyst is pre-adsorbed to NH3. After the introduction of NO+O2, the adsorbed NH3 species are gradually consumed and the nitrate species are formed. Notedly, the adsorbed NH3 bands on L-acid sites (1181 cm−1) and B-acid sites (1403 and 1437 cm−1) disappear in 3 min, the band at 1668 cm−1 (B-acid site) decreases gradually with NOx addition, and the band at 1595 cm−1 is gradually covered by bridged nitrate (1606 cm−1) (Fig. 12A). However, the bands centered at 1181 and 1595 cm−1 are gradually covered by bridged nitrate (1215, 1242 and 1606 cm−1) in 30 min over CeO2, in Fig. 12B. And various nitrates are formed on the surface of the CeO2 catalyst with the extension of time, but NH3 species is not disappeared. These results indicate that both B-acid sites and L-acid sites on W0.18CeOx are quite active in the SCR reaction, especially B-acid sites. Therefore, it can be concluded that the introduction of W significantly improves the reaction activity of adsorbed NH3 species with NOx on WaCeOx. The in-situ DRIFTS of the reaction between pre-adsorbed NO+O2 and NH3 was performed to investigate the reactivity of adsorbed NOx species over W0.18CeOx and CeO2 at 150 °C. For the W0.18CeOx catalyst (Fig. 12C), after NO+O2 pre-adsorption and N2 purging, the catalyst surface is covered with monodentate nitrite (1545 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1579 cm−1) bridging nitrate (1217, 1244 1604 cm−1), NO- species (1185 cm−1) along with nitrate species (1031 cm−1). When NH3 is introduced, the band attributed to bridged nitrate (1234 cm−1) is consumed by NH3 and the bands assigned to NH3 adsorbed on L-acid sites (1254 and 1181 cm−1) appear, and the band at 1606 is completely consumed within 2 min. In addition, the bands assigned to the adsorbed NH3 on B-acid sites (1668, 1444 and 1398 cm−1) and L-acid sites (1578, 1558, 1254 and 1181 cm−1) are formed with increasing time on the catalyst (Fig. 12). For CeO2, the intensity of the 1601 cm−1 peak (bridged nitrate) decreases significantly without completely disappearing, and may overlap with the new 1601 cm−1 peak of NH3 linked to the Lewis acid sites on CeO2 (Fig. 12D). A similar phenomenon has been found in 1244, 1545, 1558 and 1579 cm−1, too. The formation and accumulation of coordination NH4 + associated with B-acid sites (1182 cm−1) increase with time. The results above suggest that the bridge nitrates at 1606 and 1604 cm−1 play the major role in the low temperature NO conversion. The introduction of W enhances the reactivity of NOx with NH3 on the catalyst, which is conducive to low temperature SCR activity. 3.9 Effect of W addition on activity In our present work, a series of WaCeOx catalysts are synthesized for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3. The experimental results show that introducing a smaller of W species into CeO2 sample can enhance significantly the low temperature activity of NH3-SCR deNOx (Fig. S1). Among them, W0.18CeOx exhibits 100% NO conversion with 5% H2O in the temperature range of 190–490 °C, high TOF (Fig. 7) and excellent activity stability and resistance to H2O and SO2 (Fig. 1), which much better than other Ce based oxides in literatures reported [19,22,27–30,55]. Moreover, the W0.18CeOx catalyst still maintains good NH3-SCR activity and N2 selectivity after high temperature ageing and hydrothermal treatment. This is because the addition of W changes the physicochemical properties of the WaCeOx catalysts. The BET surface area of the WaCeOx catalysts is improved compared with CeO2, and W0.18CeOx has the largest specific surface area (Table 1), which can provide more active centers. However, the increase in surface area is not the main reason for such better NH3-SCR. Generally, the high oxidation ability plays key role in the enhanced low temperature activity by improving NO oxidation to NO2 to perform "fast SCR" reaction (NO2 + 2NH3 + NO → 2N2 + 3H2O). As shown in Fig. 3, the oxidation capacity only increases slightly by the oxidation tests of NO/NH3 for the WaCeOx catalysts. The results H2-TPR (Fig. 4A) and O2-TPD (Fig. 4B) display the increase in surface adsorption oxygen content on the WaCeOx catalysts, also proving the improvement of oxidation ability, and promoting the low temperature SCR activity of the WaCeOx catalysts. Obviously, the W0.18CeOx catalyst shows stronger oxidation capacity than other catalysts, corresponding to better low temperature activity. The XPS results (Fig. 6) also confirm the conclusion above. However, it is noteworthy that the slight increase in oxidation capacity of the WaCeOx catalysts can not result in their much higher low temperature SCR activity. In other word, the change of oxidation capacity is also not the main reason for such better NH3-SCR. In addition to oxidation property, acidity also plays a decisive role in the improvement of NH3-SCR activity by adsorption and activation of NH3 that is consider as key step [64–66]. The amount of B-acid and L-acid of each catalyst was calculated (Fig. 8B) according to the acid amount of NH3-TPD (Fig. 5) and the peak area proportion of each acid site obtained by in-situ DRIFTS (Fig. 8A). The Lewis acidity is primary on the CeO2, however, it is observed that Brønsted acid sites increase significantly and the Lewis acid sites decrease along with adding tungsten (Fig. 8B). Compared with CeO2, the WaCeOx catalysts exhibit extra mediate and strong acid sites, and more acid amounts, obviously the W addition improve the acidity of the WaCeOx catalysts (Fig. 5). Additionally, the in-situ DRIFTS results show that the addition of W is not only beneficial to the adsorption of NH3 species (Fig. 8), but also increases significantly the proportion of B-acid sites. Previous studies suggested that B-acid sites make for the low temperature NO conversion of the catalyst [7,13]. As displayed in Fig. S10, the relationship between TOF at different temperature (100, 130 and 160 °C) and surface B-acid percentage over the WaCeOx catalysts also clarifies that the low temperature activity increases significantly with the surface B-acid percentage from 29% (W0.06CeOx) to 84% (W0.18CeOx). The results of DRIFTS also indicate that the adsorbed NH3 species on B-acid sites of W0.18CeOx are quite active in the SCR reaction with H2O at low temperature (190 °C). Although the W0.24CeOx catalyst displays more acid content than W0.18CeOx, more surface W amount to form large W oxide clusters covers on the W0.24CeOx catalyst leading to the expose of much less surface Ce species. Moreover, surface adsorbed oxygen species and H2 consumption of the W0.24CeOx catalyst are lower than W0.18CeOx, which demonstrate much weaker oxidation ability for the W0.24CeOx catalyst combined with the results of separate NO and NH3 oxidation. Therefore, the W0.24CeOx catalyst shows lower NH3-SCR activity than W0.18CeOx. Furthermore, the excellent resistance to H2O and SO2 of W0.18CeOx can be ascribed to the fact that they have almost no influence on the NH3 adsorption (Figs. 10 and 11), and it is not easy to form the surface sulfates species on W0.18CeOx (Fig. 11). In summary, we put forward to viewpoint that the introduction of W can improve significantly the adsorption and activation of NH3 at low temperature due to the formation of lots of B acid sites on the W0.18CeOx catalyst, enhancing the reaction activity of the adsorbed NH3 species with NOx, and presenting excellent low temperature NH3-SCR activity. In a word, we propose that increasing acidity, especially B-acid content, is a strategy to design low temperature NH3-SCR denitrification catalysts by the synergistic effect between a large amount of B-acid and redox capacity. 4 Conclusions In this work, a series of WaCeOx (a = 0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) binary oxide catalysts were synthesized successfully by co-precipitation method. Among these catalysts, the W0.18CeOx catalyst shows much better low temperature activity even at high GHSV of 100,000 h−1 and 100% NO conversion with 5% H2O in a wide reaction temperature window (190–490 °C), together with near 100% N2 selectivity. Moreover, the catalyst also exhibits superior resistance to H2O and SO2, and good hydrothermal stability that the W0.18CeOx catalyst can completely convert NO in the range 235–460 °C even after hydrothermal treatment for 12 h under water vapor at 800 °C. A small amount of W can produce more B-acid sites on W0.18CeOx which enhances the adsorption and activation of NH3, bringing about the excellent low temperature SCR activity. We believe that the slight increase in oxidizing capacity of the WaCeOx catalysts does not lead to the significant high SCR activity at low temperature, but the increase of B-acid content plays a major role, that is, the synergistic effect between a large amount of B-acid and oxidation capacity enhances the denitrification activity of NH3-SCR at low temperature. This work can provide an idea for designing low temperature SCR catalyst with wide activity temperature window and high resistance to SO2 and H2O for practical applications. coredata.dc:description: Bimetallic WaCeOx (a = 0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) catalysts were synthesized for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR). The influences of W on structure, activity and surface properties were investigated by XRF, XRD, Raman, TEM, N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-TPR, O2/NH3/SO2-TPD, XPS, and in-situ DRIFTS. The characterization results show that the W/Ce ratio has a great effect on the NH3-SCR activity. The different catalytic activities of WaCeOx are mainly attributed to the acidity change, especially the increase of B-acid content plays a major role in enhancing low temperature activity. W0.18CeOx exhibits excellent low-temperature NH3-SCR activity, SO2/H2O resistance and N2 selectivity with a broad activity window (190–490 °C) with 5%H2O. Moreover, good activity window (235–460 °C) can be maintained even the catalyst treated with 5% H2O at 800 °C for 12 h, showing especial hydrothermal stability. Thus, it can be summarized that W0.18CeOx is regarded as outstanding catalyst for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO.
coredata.dc:title: Excellent low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO activity and resistance to H2O and SO2 over WaCeOx (a = 0.06, 0.12, 0.18, 0.24) catalysts: Key role of acidity derived from tungsten addition
